awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: EAGER: International Type II: Assessing the Role of Social Innovation for Resilience in Global Collaborative Research
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1.
A paramount scientific challenge is to learn from the COVID-19 pandemic crisis given the uncertainty of the timing and permanent effects on international research. Even in the unlikely event of pandemic eradication, new work patterns may replace pre-pandemic norms and practices of international collaboration. While technological solutions matter for facilitating adaptation to the pandemic, social innovations at the individual and team levels are equally or more important for generating resilience within scientific teams during the protracted crisis. The future of international collaborative work can benefit from an understanding of how scientists have shown team resilience during this time, strengthening teams, and meaningfully transferring knowledge. In an increasingly globalized scientific landscape the grand policy question is how to internationalize scientific teams while, at the same time, responding to local demands. Our goal is to characterize different forms of social innovation in international collaborative work during the pandemic, while taking into account local contexts, opportunities, and institutional factors.

Part 2.
This project addresses the topic of global social innovation in science capacity in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic by examining three intertwining features of the social dynamics of international collaborative teams: Social innovation, Adaptation and Resilience, and Learning and Transferability. Social innovation refers to new and different ways of modifying individual and group behavior within the context of team science. The research design builds on interdisciplinary knowledge about individual conduct and group dynamics within the context of teams. The project involves a series of case studies focused around distinct internationally collaborative teams across four countries: Austria, Latvia, Spain and the United States. Data are drawn from bibliometric data sources, semi-structured interviews, focus groups, and a survey of researchers. Teams include new emergent collaborations that establish norms for interaction during the pandemic, or adaptive collaborations that adjust to the barriers and constraints of the pandemic. A novel methodological approach to identifying teams for case study is employed by implementing advanced computing techniques in a new and robust bibliometric dataset, complemented by other snowball sampling techniques. The project will conclude with an international workshop to share and disseminate findings that further international collaboration.

por.por_cntn:
In today's globalized and interconnected science system, international collaborative research teams have become increasingly prevalent, as scientific collaborative endeavors present new opportunities for scientific discoveries, solution design, and innovation. This project explored how social innovations within international scientific teams adjust and adapt to uncertain and changing circumstances, specifically in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. We adopt a commonly used definition of teams: a small number of people who have complementary skills, common purpose, goals, and approach, commit to mutual accountability. This definition offers a basis for understanding how teams generate resilience under stress through innovative application of skills, synergies, shared commitment, leadership and organization structure.

The study employed a mixed-methods, multi-country case study research design to identify the characteristics of successful teams and to develop a typology of social innovations that can promote team resilience. Our focus was on teams that are primarily involved in STEM research projects, and the specific selection criteria included:

  • Country setting: partner countries represented on international collaborative teams.
  • Team context: multiple members at multiple ranks within a funded research team (projects with at least two PIs).
  • Scientific context: lab-based research, field-based research, and computational-based research have realized different effects from the pandemic which will be important to consider (codified these categories according to the description of the projects).
  • Collaborative history: new/existing collaborative ties which will reveal different aspects of resilience and innovation (through bibliometric data); and
  • Funding source: team project funding source – international – and related roles as team leaders versus participants.

Our sampling approach was purposeful and took a two-pronged approach to identify collaborative teams that meet our criteria for inclusion: a) bibliometric analysis and b) snowball sampling. First, we used bibliometric data to identify teams using co-authorship and affiliation data. Second, interviewees also recommended other individuals for further interviews.

The analysis focused on individual, group, and organizational factors that contribute to team adaptability, including adjustments in behaviors, expectations, work and resource allocation, and social interactions. The focus of the investigation is on the cohesiveness, adaptability, and leadership capabilities of teams, and how these capabilities produced different configurations of individual and collective resilience in the context of the COVID-19 crisis. Our analysis considers both the role of local (same country) and international project sub-teams. Analyses are based on interviews with project and national team principal investigators (PIs) and team members including doctoral and postdoctoral researchers.

By adding to the body of research on team resilience under crisis, this study sheds light on how team’s resilience capacity helps teams innovate their social dynamics and navigate external shocks and succeed in dynamic environments.
